Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 05:07PM PuddinTame wrote: My decision for mx wasn't made out of fear.  It was based on necessity.  DCIS can't always be seen on mammogram or MRI.  Mine was detected by mammo, but the extent wasn't.  It also didn't appear as extensive on MRI.  So, while it can seem to be "a tiny area" (what the surgeon said before the first lumpectomy), it can still result in mastectomy.  Mine did.  I found it more comforting to know what all the possibilities were and not just assume the best.  I was never surprised when things didn't work out the way we hoped.

He said I could pursue another reconstructoin option if that failed. :|  I couldn't get out of there fast enough.  The PS I'm considering for DIEP said that he wouldn't be involved in the cancer surgery or try to influence incisions or anything like that.  His office said the first priority is curing the cancer however the breast surgeon thinks is appropriate.  Then, when that's done, he'll work with what he gets from that. I kind of admired that thinking.  Cure my cancer and worry about reconstruction later.  You wouldn't want compromises made during the cancer surgery in order to ensure a better result in reconstruction. At least I wouldn't. Blessings to you! Lori

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 11:03PM PuddinTame wrote: I agree with car.  This is not something you would stand in line for, but it's not a death sentence.  You can't look at that any other way but as a blessing.   Some people think being told, "If you have to have cancer, this is best kind of have," deserves a punch in the nose.  But, it's true. Sure, I had to have a mastectomy, but I went to my son's basketball game tonight and I took food to a church friend who also had a mastectomy and I'm going back to work on Monday.  From this side, it looks okay. Truly, from the side you are on, it's a scary business.  Consider the information power--like a flowchart.  If the doc says this, then I do this.  If the doc says that, then I proceed this way.  If it's benign, you get to go to "stop".   It's scary, but you can do it, and maybe you won't have to since 80% of biopsies are benign.  Blessings to you!
